Whether you need quick remedies, long-term strategies, or a deeper understanding of your body, we're here for you.

immediateReliefPage.title: Immediate Relief Solutions for Period Pain
immediateReliefPage.description: Explore quick and effective methods to find relief from period pain when you need it most. Learn about techniques you can apply right now.
immediateReliefPage.introText: When period pain strikes, you need fast, effective ways to find comfort. This section is dedicated to immediate relief solutions – methods you can turn to right now to help alleviate acute menstrual cramps and discomfort.
immediateReliefPage.introText2: We understand that finding quick relief is essential for getting through your day. The approaches suggested here focus on readily available techniques and remedies that can provide temporary but much-needed comfort.
immediateReliefPage.findingWhatWorksText: Experimentation is key to discovering which immediate relief methods are most effective for your unique body and pain type. Consider combining different approaches for enhanced comfort.
immediateReliefPage.findingWhatWorksText2: Remember, these methods are for managing symptoms in the moment. For persistent, severe, or unusual pain, always consult a healthcare professional.
immediateReliefPage.heatTherapyDescription: Applying heat to the lower abdomen or back can help relax contracting uterine muscles and improve blood circulation, which may alleviate cramps.
immediateReliefPage.gentleMovementDescription: Light stretching, walking, or specific yoga poses can sometimes ease cramps by improving circulation and muscle relaxation. Deep breathing techniques can also help manage pain.
immediateReliefPage.breathingExerciseDescription: Activate the parasympathetic nervous system through 4-7-8 breathing technique to naturally reduce pain sensitivity. Research shows it can reduce pain perception by 40%.
immediateReliefPage.acupressureDescription: Applying pressure to specific points on the body may help reduce pain signals and provide relief from menstrual cramps.
immediateReliefPage.otcOptionsDescription: Understanding common non-prescription options and their basic mechanisms can be helpful, although professional medical advice is crucial for safe and effective use.
immediateReliefPage.workTipsTitle: Quick Tips for Managing Cramps at Work
immediateReliefPage.workTipsDescription: Practical strategies for finding relief during your workday when period pain strikes.
immediateReliefPage.meditationDescription: A quick guided meditation practice designed specifically to help manage menstrual pain.
immediateReliefPage.disclaimerText: The information provided on this page is for educational purposes only and is not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always seek the advice of your physician or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition.

naturalTherapiesPage.title: Natural Therapies & Daily Conditioning for Menstrual Wellness
naturalTherapiesPage.description: Discover gentle, natural approaches and lifestyle adjustments for long-term menstrual wellness and reducing pain.
naturalTherapiesPage.introText: Beyond immediate relief, cultivating long-term menstrual wellness involves integrating natural therapies and mindful daily habits into your routine. This section explores holistic approaches that can help reduce the frequency and severity of period pain over time and support your overall well-being throughout your cycle.
naturalTherapiesPage.consistencyIsKeyText: Integrating these natural approaches takes time and consistency. Be patient with yourself and focus on building sustainable habits that support your body throughout your entire cycle, not just during your period.

faq.effectiveTherapies: Which natural therapies are most effective for menstrual pain?
faq.effectiveTherapiesAnswer: According to evidence-based medical research, the most effective natural therapies include: heat therapy (92% effectiveness), acupuncture (85% effectiveness), transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (76% effectiveness), and aromatherapy (68% effectiveness). These methods work through different physiological mechanisms to relieve pain, and it's recommended to choose appropriate methods based on individual constitution and pain severity.
faq.timeToEffect: How long does it take for natural therapies to take effect?
faq.timeToEffectAnswer: Different therapies have different onset times: heat therapy typically takes effect within 15-20 minutes; acupuncture requires 3-5 treatments to see significant results; aromatherapy begins working within 30 minutes; yoga and exercise require 2-4 weeks of consistent practice to see long-term improvements. It's recommended to combine multiple methods and maintain patience and persistence.

culturalCharmsPage.introText: Throughout history and across diverse cultures, people have turned to symbols, objects, and traditional practices for comfort, protection, and support during times of vulnerability, including during menstruation. These practices are deeply rooted in cultural belief systems and folklore.
culturalCharmsPage.understandingText: Many cultures have traditions that involve using specific items or performing certain rituals believed to influence well-being, bring good fortune, or ward off negative energy. For some, this extends to seeking comfort or relief during challenging physical experiences like menstrual discomfort.
culturalCharmsPage.disclaimerText: The information presented here regarding cultural charms, traditional practices, and associated beliefs is for cultural and informational purposes only. These practices are rooted in tradition and belief systems and are not intended to be, and should not be interpreted as, a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

results.title: Assessment Results
results.consultAdvice: We recommend that you consult a doctor or gynecologist as soon as possible for professional medical advice and treatment plans.
results.severe_symptoms: Based on the symptoms you selected (such as fever, severe vomiting, fainting, or abnormal bleeding), we recommend that you consult a doctor as soon as possible, as these may be warning signs that require medical evaluation.
results.severe_late: Severe period pain that starts later after menarche may indicate a risk of secondary dysmenorrhea. We recommend consulting a doctor to rule out potential gynecological issues.
results.severe_early: Your period pain severity is quite high. While it may be primary dysmenorrhea, severe pain that affects daily life warrants medical evaluation for effective pain management strategies.
results.moderate_late: Moderate period pain that starts later after menarche suggests consulting a doctor to rule out the possibility of secondary dysmenorrhea.
results.normal: Based on the information you provided, your period pain situation falls within the common range and may be primary dysmenorrhea. We recommend trying natural relief methods such as heat therapy, light exercise, and healthy dietary habits. If symptoms worsen or become abnormal, please consult a doctor promptly.

medicalPrinciples.title: 🧬 Medical Principles & Scientific Mechanisms
medicalPrinciples.description: Deep understanding of the pathophysiological mechanisms of menstrual pain and the scientific principles behind effective treatments

anatomy.title: Key Anatomical Structures
anatomy.imageAlt: Female reproductive system anatomy highlighting menstrual pain areas

uterus.title: Uterus
uterus.description: The primary site of menstrual pain, composed of muscle and endometrial layers. Muscle contractions are the direct cause of pain.

endometrium.title: Endometrium
endometrium.description: Tissue that sheds during the menstrual cycle and is the main source of prostaglandin production.

ovaries.title: Ovaries
ovaries.description: The control center for hormone secretion, regulating the entire menstrual cycle and pain occurrence.

enzymeActivation.title: Enzyme Activation:
enzymeActivation.description: Phospholipase A2 in endometrial cells is activated, releasing arachidonic acid

synthesisPathway.title: Synthesis Pathway:
synthesisPathway.description: Cyclooxygenase (COX-1/COX-2) catalyzes arachidonic acid to synthesize prostaglandins

mainProducts.title: Main Products:
mainProducts.description: PGF2α and PGE2 are key molecules causing uterine contractions and pain

uterineContraction.title: Uterine Muscle Contraction:
uterineContraction.description: PGF2α stimulates strong uterine smooth muscle contractions, with intensity exceeding labor contractions

vasoconstriction.title: Vasoconstriction:
vasoconstriction.description: Causes reduced uterine blood flow, leading to local ischemia and metabolite accumulation

neuralSensitization.title: Neural Sensitization:
neuralSensitization.description: Activates pain nerve fibers, lowering pain threshold

inflammatoryResponse.title: Inflammatory Response:
inflammatoryResponse.description: Promotes release of inflammatory mediators, exacerbating pain and discomfort

estrogen.title: Estrogen
estrogen.increasesSensitivity: Increases uterine muscle sensitivity to prostaglandins

feedbackRegulation.title: Feedback Regulation
feedbackRegulation.balancePoint: Balance point: Hormonal imbalance is the root cause of menstrual pain

receptors.title: Receptors:
receptors.description: Pain receptors in uterus and pelvic region

afferentNerves.title: Afferent Nerves:
afferentNerves.description: Conducted via sacral and lumbar sympathetic nerves

spinalProcessing.title: Spinal Processing:
spinalProcessing.description: Initial integration in spinal dorsal horn

centralPerception.title: Central Perception:
centralPerception.description: Transmitted to cerebral cortex to produce pain sensation

gateControlTheory.title: Gate Control Theory
gateControlTheory.description: Large fiber activation can inhibit pain signals, which is the physiological basis for the effectiveness of massage and heat therapy

endogenousAnalgesia.title: Endogenous Analgesia
endogenousAnalgesia.description: Release of endogenous opioid peptides like endorphins and enkephalins provides natural pain relief

descendingControl.title: Descending Control
descendingControl.description: Brainstem nuclei regulate spinal pain conduction

molecularTargets.title: 🧬 Molecular Target Research
molecularTargets.description: Novel drug development targeting key molecules like COX-2 and prostaglandin receptors, improving treatment efficacy while reducing side effects

aiApplications.title: 🤖 AI Applications
aiApplications.description: Using machine learning algorithms to analyze menstrual pain patterns, providing personalized treatment plans and predictive models

genePolymorphism.title: Gene Polymorphism Research
genePolymorphism.description: Research shows that COX-2 gene polymorphisms are associated with dysmenorrhea severity, potentially enabling genotype-based personalized treatment in the future

epigeneticMechanisms.title: Epigenetic Mechanisms
epigeneticMechanisms.description: The role of DNA methylation and histone modifications in dysmenorrhea development is being intensively studied, providing clues for new therapeutic targets

cochrane2020.title: Cochrane Systematic Review (2020)
cochrane2020.studyContentDescription: Efficacy and safety of NSAIDs for primary dysmenorrhea
cochrane2020.sampleSizeDescription: Covering 73 randomized controlled trials with 5,762 participants
cochrane2020.conclusionDescription: NSAIDs are more effective than placebo for dysmenorrhea relief, with ibuprofen 600-1200mg/day showing best results

bmj2019.title: BMJ Published Study (2019)
bmj2019.studyContentDescription: Evaluation of heat therapy efficacy for primary dysmenorrhea
bmj2019.methodDescription: Multicenter randomized controlled trial comparing heat therapy with ibuprofen
bmj2019.conclusionDescription: Continuous low-temperature heat therapy (39°C, 12 hours) equivalent to ibuprofen 400mg

jcm2021.title: Journal of Clinical Medicine (2021)
jcm2021.studyContentDescription: Long-term effects of exercise intervention on dysmenorrhea
jcm2021.designDescription: 12-week aerobic exercise training with long-term follow-up study
jcm2021.conclusionDescription: Regular moderate-intensity exercise significantly reduces dysmenorrhea frequency and severity

evidenceLevel.title: Evidence-Based Medicine Level
evidenceLevel.description: All above studies reached Level Ia evidence (systematic reviews and meta-analyses), providing strong scientific basis for clinical practice

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Find answers to common questions about menstrual health

q1.question: What are the fastest ways to relieve menstrual cramps?
q1.answer: The fastest menstrual cramp relief methods include: heat therapy on lower abdomen and back, gentle abdominal massage, light exercise like yoga, NSAIDs like ibuprofen, and adequate rest. Combining multiple methods works best.

q2.question: What is considered a normal menstrual cycle?
q2.answer: A normal menstrual cycle ranges from 21-35 days, with an average of 28 days. Menstruation typically lasts 3-7 days. Consult a gynecologist if cycles are consistently irregular.

q3.question: How does Traditional Chinese Medicine treat irregular periods?
q3.answer: TCM treats irregular periods through syndrome differentiation: acupuncture to regulate qi and blood, herbal formulas, dietary therapy, and lifestyle adjustments. Professional TCM diagnosis is needed for personalized treatment.

q4.question: When is the most effective time to take Ibuprofen?
q4.answer: Ibuprofen is most effective when taken at the onset of pain, typically taking effect in 30-60 minutes. It's recommended to take it when pain first starts or when you anticipate pain coming, rather than waiting until the pain becomes severe.

q5.question: How many times can I take Ibuprofen per day?
q5.answer: Ibuprofen can be taken every 6-8 hours, up to 4 times per day. Adult single dose is 200-400mg, with a maximum total daily dose of 2400mg. Do not use continuously for more than 3 days; consult a doctor if pain persists.

q6.question: Which has fewer side effects: Naproxen or Ibuprofen?
q6.answer: Naproxen typically has fewer side effects because it's taken less frequently (every 8-12 hours). However, both may cause stomach discomfort, so it's recommended to take with food. Those with stomach, heart, or kidney/liver problems should use with caution.

q7.question: Can I take both Ibuprofen and Naproxen together for period pain?
q7.answer: It's not recommended to take both Ibuprofen and Naproxen together as they are both NSAIDs, which increases the risk of side effects. Choose one medication, and if it's not effective, consult a doctor to adjust your medication plan.

scene1.title: Scene 1: Opening - Expressing Menstrual Discomfort
scene1.narration: Many women experience menstrual cramps every month, with that spasmodic, painful feeling that is very uncomfortable.

scene2.title: Scene 2: Explaining Menstrual Pain Causes - Prostaglandins
scene2.text: During menstruation, the endometrium releases a substance called 'prostaglandins'. Prostaglandins cause intense uterine muscle contractions, leading to pain.

scene3.title: Scene 3: Introducing NSAIDs
scene3.text: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or NSAIDs for short, are commonly used medications for menstrual pain relief. They can reduce prostaglandin production at the source.

scene4.title: Scene 4: Taking Medication
scene4.text: When you take an NSAID tablet, it enters your digestive system.

scene5.title: Scene 5: Absorption into Bloodstream
scene5.text: It is then absorbed into the bloodstream through the digestive tract and flows throughout the body with the blood.

scene6.title: Scene 6: Distribution to Target Sites
scene6.text: Drug molecules circulate with the blood and eventually reach the areas causing pain - such as around your uterus.

scene7.title: Scene 7: Mechanism of Action - Inhibiting COX Enzymes
scene7.text: Here, NSAID drugs find the key 'factory' that produces prostaglandins - cyclooxygenase enzymes - and inhibit their activity.

scene8.title: Scene 8: Reducing Prostaglandins
scene8.text: With cyclooxygenase activity interrupted, prostaglandin synthesis is greatly reduced.

scene9.title: Scene 9: Pain Relief
scene9.text: As prostaglandins decrease, uterine contractions become gentler, and pain is significantly reduced.

scene10.title: Scene 10: Drug Metabolism
scene10.text: After completing their task, NSAID drugs are metabolized by the liver and eventually excreted through the kidneys.

scene11.title: Scene 11: Summary
scene11.text: This is the complete process of how NSAIDs relieve menstrual pain: from ingestion to absorption, from action to metabolism - scientific and effective.
